Package org.svvrl.goal.core.logic

Class LogicUnifier<T>

java.lang.Object
org.svvrl.goal.core.logic.LogicUnifier<T>
Type Parameters:
T - the type of logic formulae to be unified
Direct Known Subclasses:
ACTLUnifier, LTLUnifier, QPTLUnifier, REUnifier
public abstract class LogicUnifier<T>
extends java.lang.Object
This class provides some methods for the unification between two logic formulae.
Author:
Ming-Hsien Tsai

    Modifier and Type Method Description
    protected void checkSameClass​(T source, T target)
    Checks if two formulae belong to the same class.
    protected boolean consistent​(java.util.List<java.util.Map<Proposition,​T>> maps)
    A set of substitutions are consistent if all its pairs are consistent.
    protected boolean consistent​(java.util.Map<Proposition,​T> map1, java.util.Map<Proposition,​T> map2)
    Two substitutions are not consistent if they have conflict mapping.
    abstract java.util.Map<Proposition,​T> unify​(T source, T target)
    Performs unification on two formulae: source and target, and returns a proposition substitution for source such that the substituted source is equal to target.

  • Constructor Details

    • LogicUnifier

      public LogicUnifier()

  • Method Details

    • unify

      public abstract java.util.Map<Proposition,​T> unify​(T source, T target) throws UnificationException
      Performs unification on two formulae: source and target, and returns a proposition substitution for source such that the substituted source is equal to target.
      Parameters:
      source - a formula
      target - a formula
      Returns:
      a proposition substitution that renames propositions in source such that the renamed source is equal to target
      Throws:
      UnificationException - if the unification fails

    • checkSameClass

      protected void checkSameClass​(T source, T target) throws UnificationException
      Checks if two formulae belong to the same class.
      Parameters:
      source - a formula
      target - a formula
      Throws:
      UnificationException - if the two formulae belong to difference classes

    • consistent

      protected boolean consistent​(java.util.Map<Proposition,​T> map1, java.util.Map<Proposition,​T> map2)
      Two substitutions are not consistent if they have conflict mapping. For example, map1 maps "p" to "g" but map2 maps "p" to "q".
      Parameters:
      map1 - a substitution which is a map from propositions to propositions
      map2 - a substitution which is a map from propositions to propositions
      Returns:
      true if map1 and map2 are consistent

    • consistent

      protected boolean consistent​(java.util.List<java.util.Map<Proposition,​T>> maps)
      A set of substitutions are consistent if all its pairs are consistent.
      Parameters:
      maps - a list of substitutions which are maps from propositions to propositions
      Returns:
      true if maps are consistent
